leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 25] s 25 Definitions (cf Act No 52 1970, sections 110I and 110J; Act No 9 1973, sections 163 and 164; Act No 11 1970, sections 21J and 21K)

leg:heading.title: Definitions (cf Act No 52 1970, sections 110I and 110J; Act No 9 1973, sections 163 and 164; Act No 11 1970, sections 21J and 21K)

p.text: In this Part:
means a structured negotiation process in which the mediator, as a neutral and independent party, assists the parties to a dispute to achieve their own resolution of the dispute.
means a meeting arranged for the mediation of a matter.
means a person to whom the court has referred a matter for mediation.

(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 25–34, s 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.6, Sch 1.
This Part ( ss 25–34 ) does not apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court: see CPA s 4 , UCPR r 1.6 and Sch 1 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 26] s 26 Referral by court (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110K; Act No 9 1973, section 164A; Act No 11 1970, section 21L)

leg:heading.title: Referral by court (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110K; Act No 9 1973, section 164A; Act No 11 1970, section 21L)

p.text: If it considers the circumstances appropriate, the court may, by order, refer any proceedings before it, or part of any such proceedings, for mediation by a mediator, and may do so either with or without the consent of the parties to the proceedings concerned.
The mediation is to be undertaken by a mediator agreed to by the parties or appointed by the court, who may (but need not be) a listed mediator.
Without limiting subsections (1) and (2), the court may refer proceedings or part of proceedings for mediation under the Community Justice Centres Act 1983 .
[subs (2A) insrt Act 70 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2.1[1], effective 25 May 2009]
In this section, listed mediator means a mediator appointed in accordance with a practice note with respect to the nomination and appointment of persons to be mediators for the purposes of this Part.
Legislation cited in [s 26.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 20.1–20.7.
Specific rules complementing this Part are contained in Pt 20 Div 1 rr 20.1–20.7 of the UCPR.
Legislation cited in [s 26.6] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 26.

Where Supreme Court proceedings are referred to mediation under CPA s 26 , the court’s order should comply with Practice Note SC Gen 6 . The court may order the referral to a specified mediator or for the appointment of a mediator pursuant to the Joint Protocol provided for in the Practice Note. Where the court’s order requires a mediator to be appointed pursuant to the Joint Protocol, the plaintiff must, within seven days, provide the Principal Registrar with the relevant originating process and a copy of the pleadings and the Joint Protocol Referral Information.
See Practice Note DC (Civil) No 1 at [8.3] and following for requirements for mediation in District Court proceedings.
Legislation cited in [s 26.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 27, ss 56, 61.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 2.1.

The section permits the court to refer proceedings to mediation notwithstanding the absence of any agreement, either past or current, between the parties. The exercise of this power requires the court, having regard to CPA ss 56 , 61 and UCPR r 2.1 and the parties’ “good faith” obligation under CPA s 27 , to make its own assessment about the possible utility of mediation, having regard to the chance of resolving the proceedings and avoiding the costs (both tangible and intangible), the delay and the uncertainty likely to be associated with the matter proceeding to a contested final hearing. In making that assessment the court must take into account, and in appropriate circumstances may properly regard as determinative, the considered preference of a party to continue the proceedings rather than incur additional expense and delay by participating in a mandatory mediation procedure with questionable prospects of success: Morrow v Chinadotcom Corp [2001] ANZ ConvR 341; [2001] NSWSC 209; BC200101296 . Nevertheless, the power remains to order mediation, and particular circumstances may warrant its exercise despite the opposition of parties: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 427; BC200102972 (complex and protracted litigation); Daya v CNA Reinsurance Co Ltd [2004] NSWSC 795; BC200405858 (complex, multiparty litigation); Remuneration Planning Corp Pty Ltd v Fitton [2001] NSWSC 1208; BC200108793 (equivocal opposition); Lidofram Pty Ltd (as trustee for Logan Cypress & Framing Trust) v New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 1262; BC200609891 (mediation ordered despite dispute as to liability and prior break down of settlement negotiations). Referral may be considered appropriate in a wide range of circumstances — including the following:

where the court is satisfied that the parties approach to the resolution of the proceedings is being unduly influenced by subjective considerations whose effect might be minimised by the influence of a skilled conciliator: Higgins v Higgins [2002] NSWSC 455; BC200202676 (order for mediation made in family property dispute where previous resolution attempts indicated hope of compromise); Singh v Singh [2002] NSWSC 852; BC200205746 (dispute between former friends); Yoseph v Mammo [2002] NSWSC 585; BC200203626 (mediation ordered after the grant of a contested adjournment in proceedings involving a family property dispute);

where the parties are subject to an independent obligation to endeavour to mediate disputes: New Idafe Inc v Barnard [2007] NSWSC 1107; BC200708530 at [15] (requirement to mediate disputes in company constitution does not bind the court but is a factor in favour of compelling mediation);

where all parties have completed their evidence and will be able to participate in the mediation without risk of disadvantage: Dimento v Dimento [2007] NSWSC 420; BC200703077 at [5] (evidence not complete , not a “level playing field”, mediation refused); New Idafe Inc v Barnard [2007] NSWSC 1107; BC200708530 (evidence practically complete, mediation ordered);

where the nature of the proceedings and the parties satisfies the court that there is a real prospect a mediated resolution of the proceedings would be in the best interests of the parties: New Idafe Inc v Barnard [2007] NSWSC 1107; BC200708530 at [17] (proceedings concerning the affairs of a non-profit organisation — desirable that the parties reach some accommodation concerning its affairs rather than have the court impose a solution); Dimento v Dimento [2007] NSWSC 420; BC200703077 (characterisation of a dispute as a family dispute or a commercial dispute says little about whether reference to mediation is appropriate); Coric v Grotto [2007] NSWSC 1080; BC200709165 (family dispute over family property); Oasis Fund Management Ltd v ABN Amro Bank NV [2009] NSWSC 967; BC200908877 (elderly retired investors — dispute with trustee — prospects of successful early mediation — mediation ordered).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 27] s 27 Duty of parties to participate (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110L; Act No 9 1973, section 164B; Act No 11 1970, section 21M)

leg:heading.title: Duty of parties to participate (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110L; Act No 9 1973, section 164B; Act No 11 1970, section 21M)

p.text: It is the duty of each party to proceedings that have been referred for mediation to participate, in good faith, in the mediation.
Legislation cited in [s 27.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 30, 31.

Neither the CPA nor the rules impose any sanction for breach of the duty of good faith. Furthermore, the prohibitions (in CPA ss 30 and 31 ) on the admission of statements made during, and documents prepared for, the mediation, would appear to impose considerable difficulties in establishing breach of the duty: Rajski v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 476; BC200302748 . However, those prohibitions do not apply to disclosures by the mediator “in connection with” the administration of the referral provisions of the Supreme Court Act: Rajski v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 476; BC200302748 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 28] s 28 Costs of mediation (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110M; Act No 9 1973, section 164C; Act No 11 1970, section 21N)

leg:heading.title: Costs of mediation (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110M; Act No 9 1973, section 164C; Act No 11 1970, section 21N)

p.text: The costs of mediation, including the costs payable to the mediator, are payable:
if the court makes an order as to the payment of those costs, by one or more of the parties in such manner as the order may specify, or
in any other case, by the parties in such proportions as they may agree among themselves.
Legislation cited in [s 28.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.7(1).

The costs of a court ordered mediation ordinarily form part of the costs of the proceedings. On that basis a general order for the payment of costs will include the costs of the mediation: see UCPR r 42.7(1) and Newcastle City Council v Wieland (2009) 74 NSWLR 173; [2009] NSWCA 113; BC200904010 at [36]–[37] per Ipp JA. However, the court may make a separate specific order for, or the parties may agree upon, the costs of the mediation: Mead v Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 500; BC200703633 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 29] s 29 Agreements and arrangements arising from mediation sessions (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110N; Act No 9 1973, section 164D; Act No 11 1970, section 21O)

leg:heading.title: Agreements and arrangements arising from mediation sessions (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110N; Act No 9 1973, section 164D; Act No 11 1970, section 21O)

p.text: The court may make orders to give effect to any agreement or arrangement arising out of a mediation session.

On any application for an order under this section, any party may call evidence, including evidence from the mediator and any other person engaged in the mediation, as to the fact that an agreement or arrangement has been reached and as to the substance of the agreement or arrangement.

This Part does not affect the enforceability of any other agreement or arrangement that may be made, whether or not arising out of a mediation session, in relation to the matters the subject of a mediation session.

Spousal agreements affecting their respective property interests may not be enforceable unless they comply with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) especially ss 79, 86A, 90C & 90G. However, a spouse who has concluded a mediated settlement of proceedings in a state court cannot rely on non-compliance with the provisions of the Family Law Act to resist enforcement of the settlement: Grant v Grant [2012] NSWSC 725; BC201204820 (Gzell J) at [42]–[52] (equitable fraud to rely on the provisions of the Family Law Act).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 30] s 30 Privilege (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110P; Act No 9 1973, section 164F; Act No 11 1970, section 21Q)

leg:heading.title: Privilege (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110P; Act No 9 1973, section 164F; Act No 11 1970, section 21Q)

p.text: In this section, mediation session includes any steps taken in the course of making arrangements for the session or in the course of the follow-up of a session.
The same privilege with respect to defamation as exists with respect to judicial proceedings and a document produced in judicial proceedings exists with respect to:
a mediation session, or
a document or other material sent to or produced to a mediator, or sent to or produced at the court or the registry of the court, for the purpose of enabling a mediation session to be arranged.
The privilege conferred by subsection (2) extends only to a publication made:
at a mediation session, or
in a document or other material sent to or produced to a mediator, or sent to or produced at the court or the registry of the court, for the purpose of enabling a mediation session to be arranged, or
in circumstances referred to in section 31.
Subject to section 29(2) :
evidence of anything said or of any admission made in a mediation session is not admissible in any proceedings before any court or other body, and

a document prepared for the purposes of, or in the course of, or as a result of, a mediation session, or any copy of such a document, is not admissible in evidence in any proceedings before any court or other body.
Subsection (4) does not apply with respect to any evidence or document:

if the persons in attendance at, or identified during, the mediation session and, in the case of a document, all persons specified in the document, consent to the admission of the evidence or document, or
in proceedings commenced with respect to any act or omission in connection with which a disclosure has been made as referred to in section 31(c) .

level.toc-caption: [s 30.5] Enforcement of settlement agreed at mediation

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 30.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 30(4)(b), s 29(2).

heading.title: Enforcement of settlement agreed at mediation

p.text: Evidence is admissible to prove the fact and content of any agreement reached at, or as a result of, a mediation: see CPA s 29(2) (contrast Wentworth v Rogers [2004] NSWCA 109; BC200401620 (a decision based on the former provisions of the SCA). This necessarily permits the admission of such evidence where either the fact or the terms of the agreement are contentious. Indeed it may be that, even without its opening qualification, the evidentiary prohibition in CPA s 30(4)(b) does not apply to terms of settlement agreed at or after a mediation — on the basis that the agreement includes an implied consent any disclosure required for its enforcement: State Bank of New South Wales v Freeman (NSWSC, Badgery-Parker J, 31 January 1996, unreported, BC9607062); Commonwealth Bank of Australia v McConnell (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 50074/96, 24 July 1997, unreported, BC9705442).

level.toc-caption: [s 30.10] Evidence of mediation events — other than settlement agreement

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 30.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 31(b).

heading.title: Evidence of mediation events — other than settlement agreement

p.text: Evidence of settlement related negotiations, including communications involved in mediation sessions between parties, are generally not admissible. If the parties participate in consensual mediation, rather than pursuant to a reference under CPA s 26(1) the conditional prohibitions in s 131 of the Evidence Act apply: Lewis v Lamb [2011] NSWSC 873; BC201106173 . If the mediation occurs in pursuant to a reference order under CPA s 26(1) evidence related events, conduct and documents is not admissible unless either (i) they are probative of a settlement agreement or (ii) the mediating parties consent, or, perhaps, if the mediator makes a disclosure to the court “in connection with the administration of this Part”: — see CPA s 31(b) . This evidentiary prohibition includes:

evidence relating to the conduct of the parties at the mediation for example, evidence explaining the reason for the termination of the mediation: Gain v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1997) 42 NSWLR 252; (1998) NSW Conv R ¶55-826; BC9704295

evidence relating to a settlement offer made at the time of a mediation, but not in a formal mediation session: Jireh International Pty Ltd t/as Gloria Jean’s Coffee v Western Export Services Inc (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 294; BC201107168

The evidentiary prohibition does not include evidence of cancellation or refusal to attend the mediation: Al Mousawy bht Khamis v JA Byatt Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 264; BC200802023 (belated request for adjournment).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 31] s 31 Confidentiality (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110Q; Act No 9 1973, section 164G; Act No 11 1970, section 21R)

leg:heading.title: Confidentiality (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110Q; Act No 9 1973, section 164G; Act No 11 1970, section 21R)

p.text: A mediator may disclose information obtained in connection with the administration or execution of this Part only in one or more of the following circumstances:
with the consent of the person from whom the information was obtained,
in connection with the administration or execution of this Part, including section 29(2) ,
if there are reasonable grounds to believe that the disclosure is necessary to prevent or minimise the danger of injury to any person or damage to any property,

if the disclosure is reasonably required for the purpose of referring any party or parties to a mediation session to any person, agency, organisation or other body and the disclosure is made with the consent of the parties to the mediation session for the purpose of aiding in the resolution of a dispute between those parties or assisting the parties in any other manner,
in accordance with a requirement imposed by or under a law of the State (other than a requirement imposed by a subpoena or other compulsory process) or the Commonwealth.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 32] s 32 Directions by mediator (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Directions by mediator (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 3)

p.text: Subject to the uniform rules and any relevant practice notes, a mediator may, by order, give directions as to the preparation for, and conduct of, the mediation.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 33] s 33 Protection from liability for mediator

p.text: A mediator to whom the court refers proceedings has, in the exercise of his or her functions as a mediator in relation to those proceedings, the same protection and immunity as a judicial officer of the court has in the exercise of his or her functions as a judicial officer.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 34] s 34 Mediation otherwise than under this Part (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110H(2); Act No 9 1973, section 162(2))

leg:heading.title: Mediation otherwise than under this Part (cf Act No 52 1970, section 110H(2); Act No 9 1973, section 162(2))

p.text: This Part does not prevent:
the parties to proceedings from agreeing to and arranging for mediation of any matter otherwise than as referred to in this Part, or
a matter arising in proceedings from being dealt with under the provisions of the Community Justice Centres Act 1983 without having been referred under section 26 .
[s 34 am Act 70 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2.1[2], effective 25 May 2009 ; Act 106 of 2009 Sch 2.2, effective 8 January 2010]
